properties.title: Action required: Migrate to Azure Front Door Standard or Premium
properties.summary: You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Front Door (classic).
properties.description:
You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Front Door (classic).

On 31 March 2027, Azure Front Door (classic) will be retired for the public cloud, and you’ll need to migrate to Front Door Standard or Premium by that date.

Beginning 1 April 2025, you’ll no longer be able to create new Front Door (classic) resources via the Azure portal, Terraform, or any command line tools. However, you can continue to make modifications to existing resources until Front Door (classic) is fully retired.

Azure Front Door Standard and Premium combine the capabilities of static and dynamic content delivery with turnkey security, enhanced DevOps experiences, simplified pricing, and better Azure integrations. Learn more about what’s included with Front Door Standard and Premium and review the pricing of each tier.

Required action

To avoid potential disruptions in service, migrate to Azure Front Door Standard or Premium by 31 March 2027. Additionally, we recommend that you start creating new resources on Front Door Standard or Premium, and that you use Standard or Premium API and command line tools in your DevOps workflow.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

Required action

To avoid potential disruptions in service, migrate to Azure Front Door Standard or Premium by 31 March 2027. Additionally, we recommend that you start creating new resources on Front Door Standard or Premium, and that you use Standard or Premium API and command line tools in your DevOps workflow.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Front Door (classic).

On 31 March 2027, Azure Front Door (classic) will be retired for the public cloud, and you’ll need to migrate to Front Door Standard or Premium by that date.

Beginning 1 April 2025, you’ll no longer be able to create new Front Door (classic) resources via the Azure portal, Terraform, or any command line tools. However, you can continue to make modifications to existing resources until Front Door (classic) is fully retired.

properties.title: Action required: Upgrade your Azure Functions apps to .NET 8 by 12 November 2024
properties.summary: You're receiving this notice because you have one or more Azure Functions apps that use .NET 6.
properties.description:
You're receiving this notice because you have one or more Azure Functions apps that use .NET 6. 

In alignment with the end of community support, on 12 November 2024, support for .NET 6 in Azure Functions will end. Your apps that are hosted on Functions will continue to run, but security updates will no longer be available and we'll no longer provide customer service for .NET 6. Learn more about Azure Functions stack version support.

Required action

To avoid potential security vulnerabilities and take advantage of the latest features, follow the steps to upgrade your Functions apps to .NET 8 by 12 November 2024.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

properties.title: Action required: Migrate your .NET apps in Azure Functions to the isolated worker model
properties.summary: You’re receiving this notice because you use the in-process model with .NET applications in Azure Functions.
properties.description:
You’re receiving this notice because you use the in-process model with .NET applications in Azure Functions.

Beginning 10 November 2026, the in-process model for .NET apps in Azure Functions will no longer be supported. To ensure that your apps that use this model continue being supported, you’ll need to transition to the isolated worker model by that date.

You may still use your .NET apps with the in-process model beyond 10 November 2026, but they will no longer receive security and feature updates from Microsoft.

The isolated worker model offers all the same functionality as the in-process model, plus improvements such as:

  • Full control of the dependency chain.
  • Isolation from platform lifecycle activities.
  • The ability to target Standard Term Support (STS) versions of .NET.

Required action

To ensure your .NET apps in Azure Functions continue to receive support, migrate to the isolated worker model by 10 November 2026.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

Beginning 10 November 2026, the in-process model for .NET apps in Azure Functions will no longer be supported. To ensure that your apps that use this model continue being supported, you’ll need to transition to the isolated worker model by that date.

You may still use your .NET apps with the in-process model beyond 10 November 2026, but they will no longer receive security and feature updates from Microsoft.

The isolated worker model offers all the same functionality as the in-process model, plus improvements such as:

  • Full control of the dependency chain.
  • Isolation from platform lifecycle activities.
  • The ability to target Standard Term Support (STS) versions of .NET.

Required action

To ensure your .NET apps in Azure Functions continue to receive support, migrate to the isolated worker model by 10 November 2026.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You’re receiving this notice because you use the in-process model with .NET applications in Azure Functions.

Beginning 10 November 2026, the in-process model for .NET apps in Azure Functions will no longer be supported. To ensure that your apps that use this model continue being supported, you’ll need to transition to the isolated worker model by that date.

You may still use your .NET apps with the in-process model beyond 10 November 2026, but they will no longer receive security and feature updates from Microsoft.

The isolated worker model offers all the same functionality as the in-process model, plus improvements such as:

  • Full control of the dependency chain.
  • Isolation from platform lifecycle activities.
  • The ability to target Standard Term Support (STS) versions of .NET.

properties.title: Action Required: Replace any IP addresses in egress firewalls with namespace DNS names after 1 March 2024
properties.summary: You’re receiving this notice because you have one or more subscriptions using Azure Service Bus, Azure Relay, or both.
properties.description:
You’re receiving this notice because you have one or more subscriptions using Azure Service Bus, Azure Relay, or both. 

If you already use the fully qualified domain names for your specific Azure Service Bus namespaces, or the wildcard “*.servicebus.windows.net”, these will automatically resolve to the new IP addresses when the upgrade is complete. No additional action is required, and you can disregard this message.

If you’re using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. If you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. For more details on IP address and DNS changes, please visit here.

Required action

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

Additional information

  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Service Bus.
  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Relay.
  • Details on IP Address allowlisting from our documentation.

For future updates, as well as to further share these details, please visit IP address changes for Azure Service Bus and IP/DNS Changes for Azure Relay.

If you have additional questions, please contact us at Azure Service Bus - Microsoft Q&A or create a support ticket.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

Additional information

  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Service Bus.
  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Relay.
  • Details on IP Address allowlisting from our documentation.

For future updates, as well as to further share these details, please visit IP address changes for Azure Service Bus and IP/DNS Changes for Azure Relay.

If you have additional questions, please contact us at Azure Service Bus - Microsoft Q&A or create a support ticket.

If you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. For more details on IP address and DNS changes, please visit here.

Required action

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

Additional information

  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Service Bus.
  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Relay.
  • Details on IP Address allowlisting from our documentation.

For future updates, as well as to further share these details, please visit IP address changes for Azure Service Bus and IP/DNS Changes for Azure Relay.

If you have additional questions, please contact us at Azure Service Bus - Microsoft Q&A or create a support ticket.

If you already use the fully qualified domain names for your specific Azure Service Bus namespaces, or the wildcard “*.servicebus.windows.net”, these will automatically resolve to the new IP addresses when the upgrade is complete. No additional action is required, and you can disregard this message.

If you’re using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. If you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. For more details on IP address and DNS changes, please visit here.

Required action

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

Additional information

  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Service Bus.
  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Relay.
  • Details on IP Address allowlisting from our documentation.

For future updates, as well as to further share these details, please visit IP address changes for Azure Service Bus and IP/DNS Changes for Azure Relay.

If you have additional questions, please contact us at Azure Service Bus - Microsoft Q&A or create a support ticket.

You’re receiving this notice because you have one or more subscriptions using Azure Service Bus, Azure Relay, or both. 

If you already use the fully qualified domain names for your specific Azure Service Bus namespaces, or the wildcard “*.servicebus.windows.net”, these will automatically resolve to the new IP addresses when the upgrade is complete. No additional action is required, and you can disregard this message.

If you’re using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. If you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. For more details on IP address and DNS changes, please visit here.

Required action

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

Additional information

  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Service Bus.
  • Blog post regarding this update for Azure Relay.
  • Details on IP Address allowlisting from our documentation.

If you already use the fully qualified domain names for your specific Azure Service Bus namespaces, or the wildcard “*.servicebus.windows.net”, these will automatically resolve to the new IP addresses when the upgrade is complete. If you’re using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. If you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus, you'll no longer be able to connect to your namespaces. For more details on IP address and DNS changes, please visit here.

Required action

After 1 March 2024, you'll no longer be able to connect your namespaces if you’re using IP addresses in your egress firewalls for Azure Service Bus or using IP addresses or DNS names in your egress firewalls for Azure Relay. Please follow these steps to avoid potential service interruptions:

  • Update your Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay to use namespace DNS names.
  • Both Azure Service Bus and Azure Relay use several ports for their communication. Even though there have been no changes in these ports, it’s essential that you update the firewall rules for all the ports. Which you might currently use in conjunction with IP addresses. 
  • If you use Azure Relay, (WCF Relay/Hybrid Connections), you also need to configure your firewalls with the DNS names of the namespace and of all the Azure Relay gateways. This can be found by running this script. The script will resolve the fully qualified domain names of all the gateways, but you'll need to establish a connection.

More details about the ports used and functionality with Azure Service Bus or Azure Relay can be found at Azure Service Bus frequently asked questions and Azure Relay port settings.

You’re receiving this notice because you have one or more subscriptions using Azure Service Bus, Azure Relay, or both.

properties.title: Correction: The enforcement of domain fronting blocking has been postponed to 22 January 2024
properties.summary: Our previous communication contained an incorrect link resulting in some customers not being able to access the appropriate blog post. This communication fixes the error with an updated link. The rest of the messaging has been duplicated for your convenience.
properties.description:
Our previous communication contained an incorrect link resulting in some customers not being able to access the appropriate blog post. This communication fixes the error with an updated link. The rest of the messaging has been duplicated for your convenience.

You're receiving this notice because you currently use Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

On 8 November 2022, we announced that Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will stop supporting domain fronting on any resources by 8 November 2023, in accordance with Azure's policy to prohibit domain fronting.

In November 2023, we sent a follow-up announcement to remind you of the extended enforcement date to 8 January 2024, and the actions you needed to take to ensure your service continuity.

To provide you with more time and additional assistance, we have decided to postpone this enforcement date from 8 January 2024 to 22 January 2024. We're also introducing two new log fields to help you identify if an Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft (classic) resources display domain fronting behavior. These new log fields became available on 25 December 2023. It may require up to two weeks for the enforcement of blocking changes to propagate on the global point of presences starting from 22 January 2024.

We want to emphasize that enforcing the blocking of domain fronting will not have impact on regular users coming from well behaved browsers, API, SDK, etc. This enforcement will only block traffic where a website or a user explicitly tries to bypass the domain fronting check when SNI extension and HOST headers are different and aren't configured correctly on Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Recommended action

We strongly recommend that you review the blog and make the necessary changes to your configurations before 22 January 2024.

If you have further questions about domain fronting after reading the blog, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

To provide you with more time and additional assistance, we have decided to postpone this enforcement date from 8 January 2024 to 22 January 2024. We're also introducing two new log fields to help you identify if an Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft (classic) resources display domain fronting behavior. These new log fields became available on 25 December 2023. It may require up to two weeks for the enforcement of blocking changes to propagate on the global point of presences starting from 22 January 2024.

We want to emphasize that enforcing the blocking of domain fronting will not have impact on regular users coming from well behaved browsers, API, SDK, etc. This enforcement will only block traffic where a website or a user explicitly tries to bypass the domain fronting check when SNI extension and HOST headers are different and aren't configured correctly on Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Recommended action

We strongly recommend that you review the blog and make the necessary changes to your configurations before 22 January 2024.

If you have further questions about domain fronting after reading the blog, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.

It may require up to two weeks for the enforcement of blocking changes to propagate on the global point of presences starting from 22 January 2024.

We want to emphasize that enforcing the blocking of domain fronting will not have impact on regular users coming from well behaved browsers, API, SDK, etc. This enforcement will only block traffic where a website or a user explicitly tries to bypass the domain fronting check when SNI extension and HOST headers are different and aren't configured correctly on Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Recommended action

If you have further questions about domain fronting after reading the blog, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.

Our previous communication contained an incorrect link resulting in some customers not being able to access the appropriate blog post. This communication fixes the error with an updated link. The rest of the messaging has been duplicated for your convenience.

You're receiving this notice because you currently use Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

On 8 November 2022, we announced that Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will stop supporting domain fronting on any resources by 8 November 2023, in accordance with Azure's policy to prohibit domain fronting.

In November 2023, we sent a follow-up announcement to remind you of the extended enforcement date to 8 January 2024, and the actions you needed to take to ensure your service continuity.

To provide you with more time and additional assistance, we have decided to postpone this enforcement date from 8 January 2024 to 22 January 2024. We're also introducing two new log fields to help you identify if an Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft (classic) resources display domain fronting behavior. These new log fields became available on 25 December 2023. It may require up to two weeks for the enforcement of blocking changes to propagate on the global point of presences starting from 22 January 2024.

We want to emphasize that enforcing the blocking of domain fronting will not have impact on regular users coming from well behaved browsers, API, SDK, etc. This enforcement will only block traffic where a website or a user explicitly tries to bypass the domain fronting check when SNI extension and HOST headers are different and aren't configured correctly on Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Recommended action

We strongly recommend that you review the blog and make the necessary changes to your configurations before 22 January 2024.

If you have further questions about domain fronting after reading the blog, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Azure Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.

properties.title: Action recommended: Transition to using metrics in Azure Monitor by 9 January 2024
properties.summary: You're receiving this notice because you use classic metrics in Azure Storage.
properties.description:
You're receiving this notice because you use classic metrics in Azure Storage.

Because Azure Monitor now provides rich, consolidated monitoring for Azure resources, classic metrics in Azure Storage will be retired on 9 January 2024 and you'll need to transition to using metrics in Monitor.

In addition to the classic metrics features you already use, metrics in Monitor provide improvements such as:

  • New metrics and dimensions for extended monitoring.
  • Deep analysis in Azure Monitor Logs.
  • Native integration with other monitoring solutions.

Recommended action

To continue monitoring your Storage resources, transition to metrics in Monitor by 9 January 2024.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request:

  1. For Issue type, select Technical.
  2. For Subscription, select your subscription.
  3. For Service, select My services. 
  4. For Service type, select Storage Account Management.
  5. For Summary, type a description of your issue.
  6. For Problem type, select Alerts, Metrics and Logging.
  7. For Problem subtype, select Blob Storage.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

properties.title: Correction: Action required: Update your trusted root store for Azure Storage services by 29 February 2024
properties.summary: We recently sent you a notice regarding Azure Storage services. Our previous communication included an incorrect link in the support request. This notice contains the correct link for the support request. We apologize for any confusion this error may have caused. We've duplicated the original message for your convenience.
properties.description:
We recently sent you a notice regarding Azure Storage services. Our previous communication included an incorrect link in the support request. This notice contains the correct link for the support request. We apologize for any confusion this error may have caused. We've duplicated the original message for your convenience.

You're receiving this notice because you use Azure Storage services.

Many Azure Storage services use intermediate TLS certificates that are set to expire in June 2024. In preparation, we'll begin rolling out updates in March for these expiring certificates in Blob Storage, Azure Files, Table Storage, Queue Storage, static websites, and Data Lake Storage Gen2 in the public Azure cloud and US Government cloud. 

If you have client applications that still use certificate pinning, they'll be affected by this change and you'll need to take action by 29 February 2024 to avoid potential connection interruptions. Certificate pinning—when client applications explicitly specify a list of acceptable certificate authorities—is no longer a best practice.

Required action

If you have client applications that have pinned to intermediate certificate authorities, take one of these actions by 29 February 2024 to prevent interruptions to your connections:

  • Add the issuing certificate authorities to your trusted root store. Keep using the current intermediate certificate authorities until they're updated.
  • Or, to avoid the effects of this update and future certificate updates, discontinue certificate pinning in your applications.

Help and support

If you have questions, ask community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request:

  1. For Issue type, select Technical.
  2. For Subscription, select your subscription.
  3. For Service, select My services.
  4. For Service type, select Blob Storage.
  5. For Resource, select the resource you need help with.
  6. For Summary, type a description of your issue.
  7. For Problem type, select Connectivity.
  8. For Problem subtype, select Dropped or terminated connections.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

properties.title: TLS 1.3 on Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic)
properties.summary: You're receiving this notice because you're currently using Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).
properties.description:
You're receiving this notice because you're currently using Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Starting 12 February 2024, Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will support TLS 1.3 by default for improved performance and security. Please note it will take one to two weeks for this change to take effect in all global environments. No additional changes are required for your Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) resources to benefit from increased performance and security.

The supported TLS 1.3 cipher suites are:

  • TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
  • TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

TLS 1.3 is the latest version of the TLS protocol. TLS 1.3 provides better performance with a one round trip handshake instead of two to negotiate a secure connection. If the client has connected to a website or an app before, the TLS handshake will have zero round trip. It also removes older, less secure cryptographic algorithms and is less vulnerable to attacks.

Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) is a global content delivery network and global load balancer with turn-key security protections to securely accelerate contents globally. Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) support HTTPS using Transport Layer Security (TLS) to encrypt and secure communications from end to end, between clients and Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic), and between Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) and origins. Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will support TLS 1.3 from end to end if both clients and origin support it.

While most modern web browsers already support TLS 1.3, clients that do not support it will automatically negotiate with the client's highest supported TLS version (TLS 1.2, 1.1, or 1.0) based on the minimum TLS versions configured on Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic). If you enable HTTPS from Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) to origin, Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will negotiate using TLS 1.3 first and then lower versions if origin doesn't support TLS 1.3.

We highly recommend using TLS 1.3 for improved security and performance. If you experience any issues, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

While most modern web browsers already support TLS 1.3, clients that do not support it will automatically negotiate with the client's highest supported TLS version (TLS 1.2, 1.1, or 1.0) based on the minimum TLS versions configured on Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic). If you enable HTTPS from Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) to origin, Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will negotiate using TLS 1.3 first and then lower versions if origin doesn't support TLS 1.3.

We highly recommend using TLS 1.3 for improved security and performance. If you experience any issues, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.

You're receiving this notice because you're currently using Azure Front Door or Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic).

Starting 12 February 2024, Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will support TLS 1.3 by default for improved performance and security. Please note it will take one to two weeks for this change to take effect in all global environments. No additional changes are required for your Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) resources to benefit from increased performance and security.

The supported TLS 1.3 cipher suites are:

  • TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
  • TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

TLS 1.3 is the latest version of the TLS protocol. TLS 1.3 provides better performance with a one round trip handshake instead of two to negotiate a secure connection. If the client has connected to a website or an app before, the TLS handshake will have zero round trip. It also removes older, less secure cryptographic algorithms and is less vulnerable to attacks.

Please note it will take one to two weeks for this change to take effect in all global environments. No additional changes are required for your Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) resources to benefit from increased performance and security.

The supported TLS 1.3 cipher suites are:

  • TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
  • TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

TLS 1.3 is the latest version of the TLS protocol. TLS 1.3 provides better performance with a one round trip handshake instead of two to negotiate a secure connection. If the client has connected to a website or an app before, the TLS handshake will have zero round trip. It also removes older, less secure cryptographic algorithms and is less vulnerable to attacks.

Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) is a global content delivery network and global load balancer with turn-key security protections to securely accelerate contents globally. Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) support HTTPS using Transport Layer Security (TLS) to encrypt and secure communications from end to end, between clients and Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic), and between Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) and origins. Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will support TLS 1.3 from end to end if both clients and origin support it.

While most modern web browsers already support TLS 1.3, clients that do not support it will automatically negotiate with the client's highest supported TLS version (TLS 1.2, 1.1, or 1.0) based on the minimum TLS versions configured on Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic). If you enable HTTPS from Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) to origin, Azure Front Door and Azure CDN Standard from Microsoft (classic) will negotiate using TLS 1.3 first and then lower versions if origin doesn't support TLS 1.3.

We highly recommend using TLS 1.3 for improved security and performance. If you experience any issues, please submit a support request with your subscription details and your Front Door or Azure CDN from Microsoft resource information.
